comments.commentBody: The Yiddish term for this phenomenon is "mishigoss," i.e., insanity.
i don't understand how a people can support a people that are bent on your destruction

The analogy to racist whites you (LY) make is specious. Blacks in the segregated south, where I lived for five years at that time, were no threat to whites unless bigots felt that riding next to a black or attending desegregated schools was an existential threat. These Palestinians use suicide bombers and rockets to pursue their goal of extinguishing Israel. Polls of Palestinians show 90% will not accept a two state solution if it does not permit them the right to return to what is now Israel. They rejected this solution in 2000 when President Clinton tried to broker a two state solution and Arafat walked away from it. Your confidence that Israel has nothing to fear from a return to the state of Israel also ignores the massacres that occurred between the two communities when they shared equal rights during the British mandate.

The area which the Arabs have designated for a Palestinian state is at best disputed, not conquered land. There has never been a sovereign Palestinian state there in the history of the world - until 1948, there was a British Mandate and before that an Ottoman Empire and for before that, you'll have to consult your history books . Therefore this is not about Israel returning land to the Palestinians; this is about negotiating the future of that territory. The UN resolution was another Arab attempt to avoid direct negotiations with the Israelis, who are there after winning a defensive war in 1967.

Understanding situations and formulating viewpoints begin with semantics; the word you use for that land - "occupied", "disputed" or "liberated" (there indeed was once a sovereign Jewish state there) will inevitably color your viewpoint. Being against a Palestinian State today is a very unpopular viewpoint. The preponderance of Arabs in the world makes that inevitable. But, as I am sure the rabbis of BJ are aware, Jews have often held unpopular views - see Isaiah and Jeremiah.

Three cheers for these rabbis and the board. Now, I sincerely hope they will be courageous enough to urge the U.S. not to veto the Palestinians' upcoming petition to the United Nations to censure Israel for its plans to build settlements on Palestinian land in the area known as E-1.

I am pro-Israel. But I am also pro-rule of law. International law does not allow a conquering nation to keep, annex or settle land seized in war. International law requires the land to be returned.

The U.S. is not acting as a true friend to Israel if it doesn't speak up and tell Israel it has crossed too many lines for too long. If the U.S. cannot do that, then it must at least abstain from voting.

I think Israel is as afraid of the Palestinians as racist whites were afraid of blacks before passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act. Racist whites back then feared that blacks angry over the horrid way they had been treated during Jim Crow segregation would seek revenge on whites if they ever got equal rights.

Well, black people got equal rights, apartheid ended in the U.S., as it did in South Africa, and the white oppressors who so mistreated black people in each country were not massacred by the blacks as soon as they got equal rights.

I'm confident that the Palestinians won't massacre the Israelis either if the Palestinians get equal rights and get their land back to form their own state. Israel needs to learn to trust and live in peace with the Palestinians without bullying them.
Some people are more chosen than others I guess.
Don't be disingenuous, Nancy Judah.  Obviously Meatball means that their viewpoints differ because they are not raised in the U.S.  anti-Israel/pro-Palestinian sentiment is far more common abroad.
I'm not Jewish or real real smart but I think this is a joke.
The rabbis in this particular synagogue are Argentines. They're not NY Jews. I think it matters.
This is wonderful. Isn't better when human beings support freedom and dignity for all instead of being tribal all the time?

I'm sorry, but how does this work?

If you are Jewish and think the government of Israel makes some poor decisions, you are a hypocrite craving acceptance of the liberal left.

But if you are not Jewish and hold the same opinions, you are something worse, you are an anti-Semite.

How does that work?

Two questions:

1. They should condemn it to achieve consistency with an immoral, unethical past?

2. How do you know what or how all of "them" thought in their decision-making?

It is possible that "they" truly believe what they say.
As much as you do.

False and baseless accusations of anti-Semitism do nothing to lesson the courageous stand of the Synagogue in support of a Palestinian State.

While Native People were certainly treated terribly and unjustly over many years in the history of the land now called the United States, it's not as if this mistreatment occurred over the past 60 years as has happened to the Palestinian people. The fact that the Palestinian people continue to be mistreated and denied their rights by the Israeli government to this day cannot be ignored or downplayed.

The Israeli government needs to stop colonizing and taking land ib the West Bank, agree to a peace settlement with the Palestinian people and all for the creation of a Palestinian State.

It's easy for the American liberal Jews to be generous with the lives, limbs and properties of their brethren in Israel. In the meantime, they and the rest of the American left that cheers them on, sit on stolen Native American land without batting an eye lid. (Native American land, that at times were won with biological warfare.)

No matter how much these Jews crave acceptance from the liberal left, it's not going to happen.

Fairness had nothing to do with their decision to pander to the united anti Semite front.
Nicely said.  I'm a member of BJ as well.

I played one year as a senior in '57-'58 (after a two-year Army leave) just after the first indoor rink had been built. Nels Corey was our coach (tootball too). Poor team, lots of fun.
Bowdoin '56

Spot on. I would love to have Hillary on the Supreme Court. Or put both the Clintons on there.   2014 is much more important right now...and a lot can happen in Israel with the impending elections.  Bibi is giving a lot of sensible Isrealis heartburn.  His behavior doesn't go unnoticed at home or abroad.
God help us!
Neither Biden or Michelle seem to have the temperament.

The last two years have seemed like an eternity, thanks, in very large part, to the GOP and Tea Party antics. We're not even a month out from Election 2012 and you want us to think about 2016? We still have 2014 to worry about!

As others point out in their comments, a lot could happen between now and then, and four years is a long ways away. Maybe, by the close of 2014, Hilary Clinton will be Justice Clinton and we'll all be talking about a Biden/Obama ticket. You know, our current Veep and First Lady?

I believe Lymond refers to PK's most recent column. PK's column page stops with the 11/22 or 11/25 column (I forget which). The NYT general column page has no reference to PK's recent (or any) column, though it does link his most recent blog posting.

The Twitter feed and RSS feed also stop at 11/25. It's probably something Sandy-related that still hasn't been fixed.

You can get there through Mark Thoma's blog
http://economistsview.typepad.com/economistsview/2012/12/paul-krugman-th...

then look down the column to the right of whatever current entry is up, and look for "Paul Krugman: The Big Budget Mumble". Click on that, then click on the link in that entry to go to the NYT column.

But, yes, and thank you for asking: when will the Twitter and RSS feeds out for the column be back?

In Canada, there is no such thing as a thirty-year rate. The loans are typically 25 years, and rates tend to be variable. There is often just a 3 or 5 year lock available. A 10 year lock comes with a too-high interest rate.

This can be hard on borrowers. It's hard to plan for the long term if you don't know what your home loan will be in 4 years. It could be 2.5% now and 5% in four years. That's a crisis!

Yet, it seems to work. Canadians typically have more money saved for retirement than do Americans. Along with 40$/month health insurance for all, it seems like one would worry less under their system.

Fanny and Freddy are basically bankrupt and need to be liquidated.  Mortgages need to be provided by the private sector with the risk and reward going to them.  Housing will be far healthier and cheaper.

For what it is worth, the last U.S. president who truly supported affordable housing was Richard Nixon, who was influenced by the views of Daniel Moynihan, his advisor on domestic policy. It has been downhill since then.

The Times is correct that America is under-housed, and that many poor families reside in substandard housing. The rehabilitation and development of additional affordable housing is needed urgently. While the provision of such housing would be expensive, it also would create domestic jobs in construction and related fields.

As for Fannie and Freddie, they (or quasi-public institutions like them) are needed to provide liquidity to the mortgage market during times of market contraction. Turn the Fannie/Freddie secondary market function over to the private sector and I guarantee the demise of the 30-year mortgage and less predictable capital flows to the housing sector.

Something to pay attention to in the upcoming Congress is legislation aimed at reorganizing or killing off Fannie and Freddie. While those institutions must operate carefully, their outright elimination would send the housing sector back to the Great Depression.

--ANetliner

Why should Sec Clinton and President Obama do the dirty work for Israel's own citizens. They can collectively lower the broom on the PM comes election time

Burma is a willing partner with a beautiful Nobel laureate. What's not to like? So it is definitely a more worthwhile cause to take up. After all, didn't everyone get the memo: America is making a Pacific realm pivot

She's spent a lot of resources on the Middle East, financially, militarily and diplomatically. And she gets heartburn in return. With a sitting PM trying to meddle with her domestic politics. A collection of intransigent groups engaging in intra and inter sectarian warfare

This is the time for some domestic nation building. Sure, America still has the moral responsibility as the citizen of the world but that is no reason why she should stick her neck out only to get a lump of coal in her X'mas stocking

If Sec Clinton chooses to run on 2016. probably there are plenty of enthusiastic volunteers. Why not inherit some of Mr Obama's campaign staff. After all, someone has to take up the fight against the tea party extremists and the Republican WOW planks
It's now midnight Tuesday or early Weds and I can't get the puzzle or WordPlay.  Luckily I never closed this... Now I know what you all have been going thru.

As a Cooper alum, it saddens me that years of financial mismanagement has lead to this.

However, as "noble" as this protest is, the facts still remain: Cooper Union is approaching its very own financial cliff, and locking yourself in a room will not change that.

The new Cooper Union president has no ulterior motives. Why should he? He didn't create this mess. Facts are facts. There is a debt and not enough revenue. There was a big push for fundraising last year, and although record donations were received, it still is not enough.

The financial details are all available online. If anyone is keeping track, since the occupation of the Peter Cooper Suite, these numbers have not changed.
So did you use yesterday's Wordplay to avoid the spoilers on the current page?  Wouldn't it make more sense to have tomorrow's links on today's page?

Jane, we're out of sync, time wise. I left an answer to your question about "Kafka on the Shore" yesterday, and a few remarks about it which I'll repeat if you didn't get it.

It's a pity that the "improvements" didn't include numbering the main comments - so much easier to direct someone to a specific remark.
Too late to do the XWD which I just got by using the back door....yesterday's WordPlay....this is absurd... See you in the morn!

Simple words cannot convey my appreciation for this in depth article. What is laid bare here, is the very reason I subscribe to the NY Times.

I used to be a Texan.

Now, I'm not.
Amazons latest campaign says, “we’re the company with the smiley face on the box." It closer resembles the smirk of Jeffrey Bezos, the heavy handed bully who runs that despicable empire.

@Rima Regas. Dismantling the Gaza settlements was traumatic and still is unforgotten with just 8000 or so settlers removed. I am not even sure those settlers ever were compensated. Certainly it was expensive.  If you think that removing 10's of thousands of settlers, some of them fundamentalist and armed, is going to be doable or not a very steep uphill climb, I think you are far from reality as to the ease of even promising this. As well the settlements, ongoing building shows bad faith and it's disheartening and sobering to all concerned with a just settlement, not to mention anger provoking ( violence provoking) amongst Palestinians. It bolsters Iran's case against Israel to many in the region.
Way, way, way older than Hillary.

Once upon a time, in the midst of Bill Clinton's impeachment, I was a guest on The Marc Steiner Show, then on WJHU in Baltimore.  In the second hour, a caller asked us guests what we thought the Clintons would be doing ten years hence. When I said I thought Hillary would have her own political career, the laughter in that studio was matched only by the "loco" gestures from the control room.  What a crazy idea.

Hillary was careful in face of Bibi's latest.

We've made our position clear on settlements. Some European countries have also spoken out.

Israeli-Palestinian issues are complex, and they tend to get more so with time, thanks to actions from both sides. This conflict may be nearly as old as Hillary. I foresee no resolution any time soon. Unfortunately.

By the way, if Hillary decides to run, she will be a more formidable candidate than Bill C. himself was in early 90s. Now she does have an international recognition, second to none. Now rest up for next 2 years.

How is it that the unilateral Israeli withdrawal from Gaza is not cited as the strategic error that it was, not because it did not reap appreciation, but because it did not offer any connection to the Palestinean population of Gaza. Imagine if there had been a symbolic turnover of territory, rather than a disappearance from the scene... a ceremonial moment with the Other, rather than only a (necessary) concern for settlers being displaced.
It's always a zero-sum game with some people. You are against Jews and Israel if you have pity on the people who are suffering in the "townships" and Bantu-lands called the West Bank and Gaz.

I actually understand Poe’s argument. I can see how these groups might use Twitter as a recruiting tool. However, there are more important factors determining the success of these groups than access to social media. Access to weapons and money is more important, as is stability of Middle Eastern governments. The increased safety benefits of banning these accounts are negligible.

It is widely held that the government can track individuals through social media. At this point, they cannot control it. If these accounts are banned, it will set a precedent for the state to control social media, a very powerful medium. Social media has contributed to democracy in the Middle East and brought many people together. Government control of social media violates the 1st amendment by controlling a significant medium of expression. Social media is one of the best ways to fight against government tyranny so it must not be controlled by the state.

Israel's oppression will be long remembered by the Palestinian people and the tens of millions of Arabs who identify with them. It is impossible long term for Israel to tough its way through every dispute. The United States will tire of protecting the school yard bully and the result will be predictable . Make nice or pay the consequences.
How? Argentine rabbis aren't Jewish... enough? Patriotic...enough?

It is really hard to understand why you consider the idea of supporting Palestinians who want to return to the land of their birth as the equivalent of support for killing Jews.

With the great blessing of modern housing density available through high rises, many people can now live happily in relatively small bits of land. I live quite happily, for example, in Manhattan. And I understand that there are a number of cities throughout the world, London and Hong Kong come to mind, where large numbers of people live in relatively small areas of land.

My general point here is that it is not a zero sum game. Rather, envision ways to share and co-exist; you may find room for all those who want to live in the Levant and find the residents much happier than they are today.
Therefore what should happen to the Palestinians?
Oh, there is a hierarchy of Jewish people?  Do elaborate....
